questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with intermittent leg swelling for the past two weeks. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes for eight years. Examination and investigations revealed findings consistent with nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following is not a diagnostic characteristic of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased oncotic pressure

Explanation:

  • Increased oncotic pressure leads to fluid retention within the vascular system and is commonly seen in dehydration.
  • In nephrotic syndrome, oncotic pressure is reduced(d/t loss of plasma proteins), causing edema, a key diagnostic finding.

 

Diagnostic criteria for Nephrotic syndrome

Essential findings
  • Proteinuria of > 3.5 g/day (Option A)
  • Urine PCR > 2g protein/g of creatinine
  • Hypoalbuminemia - serum Albumin < 2.5 gm% (Option C)
  • Oedema due to reduced oncotic pressure

Other findings
  • Hypercholesterolemia,
  • Lipiduria (Option B)

Urine microscopy: Oval fat bodies/Maltese cross bodies

  • Low eGFR
  • Hypercoagulability

 

Causes of nephrotic syndrome:

Primary causes

Secondary causes
  • Minimal change disease (Most common in children)
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Most common in adults)
  • Membranous Glomerulosclerosis (common in older populations)
  • IgA nephropathy (rare)
  • Amyloidosis
  • Diabetic nephropathy (Most common)
  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis, like lupus nephritis
  • HIV and COVID-19

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of bilateral swelling of the legs and has a history of nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following pathophysiological changes is primarily responsible for the fluid retention in his condition?
questions.solution:
In nephrotic syndrome, fluid retention is primarily due to sodium retention in the kidneys. This occurs because of reduced oncotic pressure from hypoalbuminemia, leading to decreased effective circulating volume and triggering compensatory mechanisms such as the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which promotes sodium and water retention, leading to oedema.

Nephrotic Syndrome  
Clinical manifestations Pathophysiology
Proteinuria The damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to increased permeability to proteins. (Option B)
Odema

Hypoalbuminemia


 
  • Due to urinary loss of albumin being more than its synthesis by the liver.
  • Muehrcke's lines (linear white lines in the nail bed seen in hypoalbuminemia)
Hyperlipidemia

Xanthoma and xanthelasma can be appreciated.
Hypercoagulability

This can be due to factors like:

  • Due to the loss of anticoagulant proteins like Protein C/ Protein S/ Antithrombin III
  • Ferritin deficiency
  • History of factor V Leiden mutation
  • Increased production of procoagulant factors by the liver.
Infections Loss of immunoglobulins in urine causes hypogammaglobulinemia, increasing susceptibility to infections.

Decreased production of aldosterone (Option A) can result from primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, certain medications, or severe illness, leading to hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, volume depletion, and hypotension. In nephrotic syndrome, aldosterone production is increased as a compensatory response to hypoalbuminemia and low effective blood volume, leading to oedema.


 

Increased renal perfusion pressure (Option C) occurs due to elevated blood flow pressure to the kidneys, often seen in conditions like hypertension and increased blood volume. In nephrotic syndrome, decreased renal perfusion may occur due to the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) in response to hypoalbuminemia, leading to vasoconstriction.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman presents with signs of nephrotic syndrome and has a renal biopsy that confirms Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). She has no significant medical history and no history of drug use. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?


	Urine analysis shows nephrotic proteinuria and hematuria.
	Urine PCR is < 2
	Podocyte foot process effacement is seen in electron microscopy
	Metolazone is contraindicated for refractory edema.
	More common in African-descent
questions.solution:
• Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli and presents with proteinuria, a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • Biopsy findings include segmental sclerosis on light microscopy, mild IgM and C3 deposition on immunofluorescence, and podocyte foot process effacement with capillary loop collapse on electron microscopy.
Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis  

Pathogenesis

(In primary condition)


 

Podocyte injury ➜ Podocytopenia ➜ Synechiae formation between the GBM & parietal epithelial cells ➜ Glomerulosclerosis.
Clinical manifestation
  • Microscopic hematuria
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria (often significant) (Statement 1)
  • Hypertension
  • Edema, starting with periorbital swelling
  • Declining eGFR over time
More common in individuals of African-American descent (Statement 5)
Investigations
  • Kidney function test: Reduced eGFR
  • Urine microscopy: Shows hematuria
  • Urine PCR: >2 g/g proteinuria
  • Biopsy (USG-guided) Findings: (Diagnostic)
    • Perihilar sclerosis with hyalinosis
    • Hyalinosis and adherence lesion between tuft and Bowman’s capsule
    • Sclerosing tip forming adherence to tubular pole
  • Electron microscopy:
Podocyte foot process shows eﬀacement (Statement 3)
Treatment
  • For Primary FSGS:
  • Proteinuria: Steroids & Cyclosporin can help in remission for people responding to steroids.
  • HTN: ARB/ACEi
  • Edema: Thiazide diuretics
  •  
  • Refractory edema: Metolazone + Furosemide (Statement 4)
    • Spironolactone can be initiated after the edema subsides.
  • Low salt diet
  • For Secondary FSGS, management is based on the cause of the condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male visits the outpatient clinic with a 2-month history of worsening leg swelling and increased fatigue. He notes that his urine has been foamy for several weeks. On examination, he displays bilateral lower extremity edema and hypertension. A renal biopsy reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following is not a cause of primary FSGS?
questions.solution:
• The HBB gene mutation is primarily associated with hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia, which can lead to secondary FSGS due to factors like hypoxia or micro infarcts.
  • Mutations in podocin, APOL1, and TRPC6 are linked to primary FSGS, as they directly affect podocyte structure and function.

 

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Category

Primary FSGS

Secondary FSGS

Causes
  • Mostly Idiopathic
  • Can be due to mutations in
    • APOL 1,
    • TRPC6 (Autosomal dominant)
    • Podocin (autosomal recessive)
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • HIV
  • HBV
  • Human parvovirus B19
  • CMV
  • EBV
  • Reflux nephropathy
  • Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
  • Alport syndrome
  • Drugs like
    • INF α
    • Heroin
    • Pamidronate
    • Lithium
    • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

Presentation

Commonly as Nephrotic syndrome

Mostly asymptomatic can present with nephrotic range proteinuria but not the syndrome

Immunofluorescence

Presence of IgM + C3

Minimal to no change

 

Morphological Variants of FSGS
Classical variant
  • Most common
  • Presence of focal and segmental IgM & C3
  • Podocyte foot process effacement.
Tip variant
  • Presence of at least one segmental lesion involving the tip.
  • Tip lesions can be cellular or sclerosing.
Perihilar variant
  • Presence of at least one glomerular perihilar hyalinosis
  • Exclude the other types.
Cellular variant

Occluding segmental endocapillary hypercellularity in at least 1 of the glomerulus.
Collapsing variant
  • Collapsed glomeruli.
  • Hyperplasia and hypertrophy of podocytes (pseudo-crescent)
  • Microcysts within dilated tubules
  • Electron microscopy: Interferon footprints
  • This has the worst prognosis and is commonly seen with HIV, pamidronate, and parvovirus infection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with worsening leg and abdominal swelling, frothy urine, and weight gain over two months. Examination shows significant edema and HTN. Lab tests indicate nephrotic range proteinuria and a renal biopsy reveals thickened glomerular capillary walls with subepithelial immune complex deposition. Which antibodies are most commonly associated with the primary form of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation and biopsy findings suggest Membranous nephropathy, a type of nephrotic syndrome characterized by thickened glomerular capillary walls and subepithelial immune complex deposition (Spike & Dome pattern).
  • In primary membranous nephropathy, PLA2R antibodies (Phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies) are commonly present in about 70-80% of patients. While they can appear in secondary cases related to sarcoidosis, certain cancers, and hepatitis B, they are primarily associated with the idiopathic form.

 

Glomerulonephropathy

Primary causes

Secondary causes
  • PLA2R antibodies (seen in 70%)
  • Anti - thrombospondin 7a ( 3 - 10 %)
  • Infections: Syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis, leprosy, filariasis, hepatitis B and C .
    • Anti-HBc IgM antibodies (Option C) are indicative of recent hepatitis B infection, specifically targeting the hepatitis B core antigen.
  • Autoimmune conditions:
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Anti-CCP antibodies) (Option A)
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis
  • SLE (Anti-Smith antibodies) (Option B)
  • Cancer: Lymphoma, leukemia, and other organ carcinomas (GI, prostate, breast, lung, bladder)
  • Drugs: Gold, mercury, d-penicillamine, NSAIDs, probenecid, captopril.
  • Other systemic conditions: Fanconi’s syndrome, Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), sickle cell anemia, diabetes.

 

  • Clinical manifestations of MGN:
    • Microscopic hematuria
    • Proteinuria with foamy urine
    • Elevated blood pressure
    • Periorbital edema, pedal edema and anasarca
    • Commonly present with Nephrotic syndrome
    • MGN commonly leads to renal vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and DVT (thromboembolic complications); hence, regular monitoring and appropriate management are necessary to avoid these.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is being evaluated for membranous nephropathy. Which of the following statements regarding membranous nephropathy is not true?

choices.text: Light microscopy reveals subepithelial immune complex deposits
Granular deposits are seen in Immunofluorescence
Increased risk of renal vein thrombosis

questions.solution:
Light microscopy in membranous nephropathy shows thickened glomerular capillary walls, while electron microscopy identifies subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Investigations of Membranous Nephropathy:

  • Kidney function tests reveal increased creatinine
  • Urine Protein: >2gm protein/gram of urinary creatinine
  • Renal biopsy:
    • Light Microscopy: Reveals uniform basement membrane thickening along peripheral capillary loops.

 

    • Immunofluorescence: Diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3 (Option C)
    • Electron Microscopy: Dense subepithelial deposits
      • Spike & dome appearance (arrows & asterisk)

 

  • Autoantibody Testing:
    • Autoantibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) (Option B) are present in 70% of cases.
    • Thrombospondin type-1 domain containing 7A (THSD7A) (3-10%)
    • Secondary MGN often lacks these autoantibodies.

 

Management of Membranous Nephropathy:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Manage edema (Thiazide diuretics), dyslipidemia, and hypertension (ACE inhibitors/ARBs)
  • Immunosuppressive Therapy: For primary MGN with persistent proteinuria (>3g/24 h)
    • Corticosteroids
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Chlorambucil
    • Mycophenolate mofetil
    • Cyclosporine
    • Rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody)
  • Prophylactic Anticoagulation may be recommended for patients with hypoalbuminemia due to the risk of thrombotic complications.

 

Complications:

  • Increased risk of Renal vein thrombosis (Option D)
  • Others: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to hypercoagulability associated with nephrotic syndrome.

 

Prognosis:

  • One-third of patients progress to more severe disease.
  • One-third experience spontaneous remission.
  • One-third maintain stable disease.
  • Factors associated with a poorer prognosis include male gender, older age, hypertension, and persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital nephrotic syndrome presenting with significant edema, low serum albumin, and a history of repeated infections. Which of the following is a common genetic mutation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The NPHS1 gene mutation, which encodes nephrin, is the most common cause of congenital nephrotic syndrome, particularly the Finnish type.

 

Congenital nephrotic syndrome:

  • It refers to nephrotic syndrome with onset within the first 3 months of life.
  • It is characterised by:
    • Anasarca (generalised oedema)
    • Hypoalbuminemia (low blood albumin levels)
    • Oliguria (reduced urine output)
    • Increased susceptibility to infections, particularly with encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).
  • Etiology: Mutations in the genes that affect slit pore membrane at birth
    • NPHS1 gene mutation encoding nephrin - Finnish type (Most common)
    • NPHS 2 (Option C) gene mutation encoding podocin.
    • α-Actinin 4
    • α-3 Integrin mutation (Option D): Congenital nephrotic syndrome with skin and lung involvement.
    • WT1 mutation (Option A): Denys-Drash syndrome.
    • Other causes: congenital infections (such as syphilis, cytomegalovirus, and toxoplasmosis) and mutations in the PLCE1 genes.

 

  • Clinical course: Patients often experience failure to thrive, recurrent infections, hypothyroidism, and progression to renal failure by ages 2 to 3.
  • Screening and Diagnosis:
    • Elevated Alpha-Fetoprotein (AFP) in maternal serum and amniotic fluid allow for antenatal screening.
    • Urine spot PCR > 2
    • Serum albumin < 2.5 g/dL
    • Elevated serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels.
  • Management: No specific treatment
    • Appropriate nutrition and reduce proteinuria using ACEI/Indomethacin.
    • Regular intravenous albumin infusions (every 2-3 weeks) help prevent severe hypoalbuminemia and manage anasarca.
    • Many patients exhibit hypothyroidism due to loss of thyroid-binding globulin and benefit from oral thyroxine supplementation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with periorbital oedema and leg swelling that began a week ago. Laboratory tests reveal 4+ proteinuria and low serum albumin. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are normal. Light microscopy of a renal biopsy reveals no glomerular lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation, with periorbital swelling, leg oedema with proteinuria, normal renal function tests, and no lesions visible in light microscopy, points towards Lipoid nephrosis or minimal change disease.

 

Minimal Change Disease (MCD):

  • Accounts for 70–90% of nephrotic syndrome cases in children and 10–15% in adults.
  • Typically presents as a primary renal condition but can be associated with various factors, including Hodgkin's disease, allergies, NSAID use, lithium & infections.

It commonly affects boys with age of onset between 2-6 years.

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Periorbital oedema is often the first noticeable symptom, which subsequently progresses to generalised oedema, including involvement of the legs, ascites, hydrothorax, and hydrocele.
    • Average urine protein excretion of approximately 10 g/day, resulting in severe hypoalbuminemia & acellular urinary sediment.
    • Less common features:
      • Hypertension (30% in children, 50% in adults)
      • Microscopic hematuria (20% in children, 33% in adults)
      • Atopic symptoms (40% in children, 30% in adults)
      • Decreased renal function (25–40%)
  • Histological Findings:
    • Light Microscopy: No glomerular lesions are visible
    • Immunofluorescent microscopy: Negative for deposits, though small amounts of IgM may occasionally be detected in the mesangium.
    • Electron Microscopy: Effacement of the foot processes of podocytes
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Heavy proteinuria (3+ to 4+) & low serum albumin, often <1 g/dL.
    • BUN and Creatinine levels: Typically normal unless hypovolemia/AKI is present.
    • Normal C3 levels
  • Treatment:
    • Prednisolone: Responds well with 90% remission.
      • Initial dose: 60 mg/m²/day (or 2 mg/kg, maximum 60 mg) for 6 weeks.
      • Followed by 40 mg/m² (or 1.5 mg/kg, maximum 40 mg) as a single morning dose on alternate days for the next 6 weeks.
    • Extending initial therapy beyond 12 weeks is not recommended due to the increased risk of side effects without significant benefits.
    • Second-line Immunosuppressives: Cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, and mycophenolate mofetil for frequent relapsers or steroid-resistant cases.

 

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option A) typically shows focal sclerotic lesions on light microscopy. Due to impaired kidney function, it often presents with normal to elevated BUN and creatinine levels, which do not align with the patient's normal results.

 

Membranous Nephropathy (Option C) usually occurs in older adults and is characterised by subepithelial deposits seen on electron microscopy and the thickening of the basement membrane on electron microscopy.


Diabetic Nephropathy (Option D) generally occurs in older patients with a history of diabetes. It presents with specific changes in kidney function over time, and light microscopy shows nodular glomerulosclerosis, which is not present in this case.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with nephrotic syndrome has experienced multiple relapses over the past year. He responds well to treatment with prednisolone, but his symptoms recur shortly after tapering the medication. According to the clinical definition, what qualifies a patient as having frequent relapses of nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Three or more relapses in any 12 months
Three or more relapses within a year after stopping treatment
Two relapses on a spacing of 6 months

questions.solution:
Frequent relapses in nephrotic syndrome are defined as having three or more relapses within any 12 months (or) two or more relapses within the first 6 months.

 

Terminologies related to Nephrotic syndrome:

  • Remission:
    • Urine albumin-Nil/trace on the dipstick for 3 consecutive days and urine protein < 4 mg/m²/hr.
    • The protein-to-creatinine ratio is less than 0.2 mg/mg.
  • Relapse:
    • Urine albumin is 3+ to 4+ for three consecutive days, and proteinuria is > 40 mg/m²/hr.
    • Spot PCR > 0.2 mg/mg following a period of remission.
  • Frequent Relapses: (After stoppage of treatment)
    • Two or more relapses within the first six months
    • Three or more relapses in any 12 months
  • Steroid Dependence: Two consecutive relapses while on alternate-day steroids or within 14 days of discontinuing steroids.
  • Steroid Resistance: Absence of remission despite treatment with prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg (60 mg/m²) per day for six weeks.

 

Feature

Steroid-Responsive Nephrotic Syndrome

Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome

Definition

Nephrotic syndrome that responds well to corticosteroid treatment.

Nephrotic syndrome that does not improve despite adequate corticosteroid treatment (e.g., prednisolone at 2 mg/kg/day for 6 weeks).

Types:

  • Initial Steroid Resistance: Lack of response from the onset.
  • Late Steroid Resistance: Resistance develops after initial response.

Common Type

Minimal Change Nephrotic Syndrome (MCNS) accounts for about 80% of cases in children.

It is often associated with Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) or genetic mutations affecting podocytes.

Diagnosis

Diagnosed without kidney biopsy; characterised by heavy proteinuria, low serum albumin, and no significant glomerular damage.

Further investigation (e.g., kidney biopsy) is required to determine the underlying cause.

Management

Responds to high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone), leading to remission of proteinuria and oedema within 10-14 days.

Treatment may include immunosuppressive agents, calcineurin inhibitors, or other therapies, as corticosteroids are often ineffective.


 

Significant Steroid Toxicity: (For Steroid dependent NS)

  • New or worsening obesity (BMI >27 kg/m², equivalent to adult BMI).
  • Hyperglycemia.
  • Behavioral or psychiatric disorders.
  • Slow growth (height velocity <25th percentile and/or height <3rd percentile).
  • Glaucoma or cataracts.
  • Avascular necrosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with complaints of dark, "cola-colored" urine, swelling of her legs, and a headache. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and urinalysis reveals hematuria, red blood cell casts, and mild proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The combination of hematuria, red blood cell casts, hypertension, and cola-coloured urine in a child is most indicative of acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Nephritic syndrome), often following a streptococcal infection.
  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) (Option A), Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option B), and Membranous Nephropathy (MN) (Option D) come under Nephrotic syndrome, where these symptoms are not commonly seen.

 

Acute nephritic syndrome:

  • Classically presents with hypertension, hematuria, red blood cell casts, pyuria, and mild to moderate proteinuria.
  • Significant inflammatory damage to the glomeruli results in a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR), ultimately leading to uremic symptoms, salt and water retention, and the development of oedema and hypertension.
  • Mechanisms:
    • Inflammation: A primary factor in glomerular injury.
    • Reactive cell proliferation: Cellular responses to inflammation.
    • Breaks in Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM): Structural damage affecting filtration.
    • Crescent formation: A pathological feature indicative of severe glomerular injury.
  • Pathophysiology:
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hematuria: Characterized by red or brown urine (Cola coloured urine)
    • Edema
    • Hypertension: Sudden elevated blood pressure.
    • Oliguria: Reduced urine output.
    • Reduced renal function: Deterioration in kidney function.
    • Subnephrotic proteinuria

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who reports he has felt unwell for the past week. He had a sore throat, cough, and fever 10 days ago and now has swelling around his eyes and legs. His urine sample looks dark (shown below). What parameters are commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes a child with a history of sore throat, cough, and fever, followed by pedal oedema, periorbital swelling, and cola-coloured urine, diagnosed as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), characterised by decreased C3 levels.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)
Cause Group A β-Hemolytic streptococci
Pathogenesis

Immune-complex mediated (Type III hypersensitivity reaction)
Clinical manifestations
  • It is more common in children and young adults.
  • History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks).
  • Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain)
  • Periorbital and pedal oedema
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy:
    • Abrupt rise in BP
    • Headache
    • Loss of consciousness
  • Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting.
Test for antibodies
  • Anti- DNAse
  • Anti-Hyaluronidase
  • ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer
Lab findings

Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark (cola-colored) on standing (hematuria).

  • Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc). (Option A)
  • Raised serum potassium (Option C)
  • Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50 (Option D)

Normal serum C4 level. (Option B)
Pathological findings

Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys

Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells).

Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition)

Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition).
Management
  • Self-limiting disorder
  • Conservative and supportive management involves:
    • HTN crisis: Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside
    • Pulmonary edema: Furosemide
    • Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin)
    • Dialysis if needed

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who reports episodes of blood in his urine starting two days after a common cold, along with occasional abdominal pain. The child is vitally stable. Investigations show hematuria with normal kidney function tests and C3 levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy), which is characterised by episodes of hematuria occurring shortly after respiratory infections (such as a common cold). The presence of normal kidney function tests and C3 levels further supports this diagnosis.

Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy)  
Pathophysiology
Clinical features
  • Incidental finding
  • Macroscopic hematuria (recurrent) following an upper respiratory infection (URTI)
  • Asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (persistent)
  • If this patient develops an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI), microscopic hematuria can progress to macroscopic (gross) hematuria within 48 hours.
  • Normal blood pressure
  • Normal urine output
Lab findings
  • Normal values of renal function test (serum creatinine, serum urea, etc.)
  • Normal urine output
  • Normal serum C3 level
Pathological findings

Light microscopy: Mesangial proliferation.

Immunofluorescent microscopy: Mesangial deposition of IgA.
Management
  • There is no optimal treatment, but the following drugs are used:
    • ACE-i (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors) like captopril and enalapril.
    • Steroids (when the patient has recovered from URTI)
    • Fish oil and tonsillectomy are suggested in studies.

Minimal change disease (Option A), also known as NIL lesion or lipoid nephrosis, is mostly idiopathic but can be triggered by NSAIDs or Hodgkin's lymphoma. Symptoms include puffy eyes, weight gain, pleural effusion, and ascites, but hematuria is uncommon A kidney biopsy shows IgM deposits on light microscopy and podocyte effacement on electron microscopy.

Alport syndrome (Option C) is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting from the deletion of the COL4A5 gene (type IV collagen). It is characterized by hematuria, neurosensory hearing loss, and lens ocular deformities, which are absent in the given scenario. Electron microscopy of the glomerular basement membrane shows a Basket-weave appearance (irregular thickening and thinning, along with pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa).

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (Option D) is an acute variant of IgA nephropathy that presents with a characteristic tetrad of symptoms: a petechial rash (buttocks and lower legs), abdominal pain (gastrointestinal vasculitis), arthralgia, visible or non-visible hematuria, with or without proteinuria (renal disease). Renal biopsy reveals mesangial IgA deposition. Though it shares IgA deposition with Berger’s disease, the clinical presentation here points to Berger's.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue, leg swelling, and decreased urine output following an upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. Urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria. The histopathological findings of renal biopsy are shown below. All of the following are associated with Type II of this condition, except,
questions.solution:
Option C) Wegener granulomatosis

 

The clinical scenario of swelling, decreased urine output after an upper respiratory tract infection, hematuria, and proteinuria, along with image findings showing crescents, suggests Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or Crescentic Glomerulonephritis, with Wegener granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) being associated with Type III RPGN.

 

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or Crescentic Glomerulonephritis:

  • It is a clinical syndrome characterised by severe glomerular injury, leading to rapid loss of renal function, severe oliguria, and signs of nephritic syndrome such as hematuria, proteinuria, and oedema.
  • Histopathological finding:
    • Proliferation of glomerular parietal epithelial cells and inflammatory cells (cellular crescents) surrounds the capillaries (glomerular tuft).
  • Electron microscopy: Shows rupture and wrinkling of basement membrane.
  • Types of RPGN
 

Type I RPGN

Type II RPGN

Type III RPGN

Cause

Anti-GBM antibody

Immune (antigen-antibody) Complex

Pauci-immune

Associated conditions

Goodpasture syndrome
  • Idiopathic
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)
  • Lupus nephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  • IgA nephropathy
  • ANCA-associated
  • Idiopathic
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis
Immunofluorescent microscopy

Linear or ribbon-shaped appearance

It shows a starry sky (lumpy, bumpy, or granular) appearance or garland pattern.

-

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath over the past few days. He also reports recent leg swelling and decreased urine output. Investigations show hematuria and proteinuria, along with positive anti-GBM antibodies. Which chain of type IV collagen is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient’s presentation, with hemoptysis, hematuria, and anti-GBM antibodies, suggests Goodpasture syndrome, a form of anti-GBM disease.
  • This condition is associated with antibodies directed against the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen (Type II hypersensitivity reaction) found in the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes.
  • Clinical features:
    • Hemoptysis or blood in the sputum (pulmonary haemorrhage)
    • Hematuria due to glomerulonephritis.
    • Associated with Type I RPGN (Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis)
  • Cause of death: Uremia (most common)

Immunofluorescence shows a linear or ribbon-like appearance.

lpha-4 chain (Option B):

  • Benign familial hematuria, also known as thin basement membrane nephropathy (TBMN), is caused by a defective alpha-4 chain of type IV collagen.
  • Although mild to moderate proteinuria may occur, renal function remains normal.
  • Electron microscopy showing thin basement membrane:

 

Alpha-5 chain (Option C):

  • Alport syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder characterised by hematuria, neurosensory hearing loss, and lens ocular deformities (Anterior lenticonus).
  • It results from the deletion of the COL4A5 gene (alpha-5 chain of type IV collagen).

Electron microscopy of the glomerular basement membrane shows a Basket-weave appearance (irregular thickening and thinning, along with pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa).

Light microscopy of a normal glomerulus shows well-defined capillary loops, a thin and intact glomerular basement membrane, normal mesangial cells, and no signs of cellular proliferation or sclerosis. The architecture is preserved without any deposits or abnormalities.
